titleStmt.title: Path-aware Siamese Graph Neural Network for Link Prediction

analytic.title: Path-aware Siamese Graph Neural Network for Link Prediction

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we propose an algorithm of Path-aware Siamese Graph neural network(PSG) for link prediction tasks. Firstly, PSG can capture both nodes and edge features for given two nodes, namely the structure information of k-neighborhoods and relay paths information of the nodes. Furthermore, siamese graph neural network is utilized by PSG for representation learning of two contrastive links, which are a positive link and a negative link. We evaluate the proposed algorithm PSG on a link property prediction dataset of Open Graph Benchmark (OGB), ogbl-ddi. PSG achieves top 1 performance on ogbl-ddi. The experimental results verify the superiority of PSG.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: The task of link prediction is often used to predict missing links in static networks. It is widely applied in the scenarios of recommender system [1], social network analysis [2], biocomputing [3], computational pharmacy [4], knowledge graph [5] and other graph based network analysis. Generally speaking, it can be inferenced by computing the similarity of the nodes to judge whether missing links exist between two nodes. This straightforward idea lead to research direction on the similarity measures and representation learing of graph nodes. Intuitively, common neighbors can measure the similarity of two nodes, therefore stimulate heuristic based methods on the context of nodes. Furthermore, network embedding methods are studied as representation learning to explore latent factors as feature vectors of nodes. Recently, GNN based methods have been widely applied to the work of neural link predition due to its nonlinear feature extraction power of graph structure [6,7].

For computational pharmacy, an important link prediction task is to predict drug-drug interactions given information on already known drug-drug interactions, as the joint effect of taking the two drugs together is considerably different from the expected effect in which drugs act independently of each other. Given ogbl-ddi dataset of Open Graph Benchmark (OGB) [8], which is a homogeneous, unweighted, undirected graph, representing the drug-drug interaction network [9], the objective is to rank true drug-drug interaction higher than false drug-drug interaction. In the OGB leaderboard, existing approaches mainly focus on graph neural networks that capture node features of neighborhood, while some ones integrate edge features, such as distance encoding [10], into existing GNN framework. In addition, based on GraphSage [11], PLNLP [12] introduces pairwise loss funtion, which is common in siamese network for ranking problem, and achieves better performance.

However, none of the above methods simultaneously builds a siamese graph neural network for link prediction as ranking problem and utilizes both nodes and edge features. Therefore, we propose an algorithm of Path-aware Siamese Graph neural network(PSG) for link prediction tasks. Firstly, PSG can capture both nodes and edge features for given two nodes, namely the structure information of k-neighborhoods and relay paths information of the nodes. Furthermore, siamese graph neural network is utilized by PSG for representation learning of two contrastive links, which are a positive link and a negative link. We evaluate the proposed algorithm PSG on a link property prediction dataset of Open Graph Benchmark (OGB), ogbl-ddi. PSG achieves top 1 performance on ogbl-ddi. The experimental results verify the superiority of PSG.

In the following, we will present our work in four sections. Section 2 introduces related work on link prediction and graph neural network. Section 3 formally defines the link prediction problem, and presents our solution PSG model. Section 4 shows experiments and evaluation details of the proposed PSG model. Finally, Section 5 summarizes our work.

div.head: RELATED WORK
div.p: In this section, related work on link prediction and graph neural network is presented as follows.

div.head: Link Prediction
div.p: For the task of link prediction, lots of approaches are proposed to improve the effectiveness and efficency for kinds of applications. Among those approaches, four main categories can be summurized as follows: neighborhood based, factor decomposition based and neural network based. Neighborhood based methods mainly utilize wide-based or depth-based neighborhood information to measure nodes similarity, such as common neighbors [13], Adamic-Adar [2], SimRank [14] and Node2Vec [15]. As the former method only focus on the explicit factors of graph, factor decomposition based mothods mine the implicit factors that reconstruct the raw graph structure or adjacent matrix, such as MF [16], PNRL [17]. Furthermore, to capture deep hierarchical structure features, neural network based methods are proposed to perform end-to-end encoding of graph structure features with neural layers, such as GCN [18], SEAL [19].

div.head: Graph Neural Network
div.p: Deep neural networks have achieved great success in Euclidean domains, such as computer vision [20], speech synthesis and recognition [21], natural language understanding [22]. It inspires the research of graph neural networks on non-Euclidean domains, such as recommender system, social network analysis, drug discovery and knowledge graph. In earlier stage, based on the theory of convolution in digital signal process, spectral domain-based graph neural networks attract lots of attention and research [6,7]. Graph Convolutin Network(GCN) [18] is one of the most famous model that achieves better performance than traditional methods. As time and space complexity of GCN is high, variants of spectral domain based methods [23,24] aim to reduce the time cost and space cost, and to generate better approximations and performance. Furthermore, spatial domain based methods are proposed to directly encode local structure features based on neighborhood aggragation and graph pooling [25]. As computations increase exponentialy with the increase of neighborhood range, sampling methods [11] and attentions methods [26] are proposed to solve the problem of computation efficiency. As a side effect, the methods often improve the final performance as the extracted information and the capacity of neural layers increase. These methods can also be regarded as graph reconnection approaches.

div.head: METHOD
div.p: In this section, we will present the problem definition and our solution PSG model.

div.head: Problem Formulation
div.p: Let = ( , ) represents the homogeneous, unweighted, undirected graph, representing the drug-drug interaction network, where represents the nodes set of the graph, and ? ? represents the edes set of the graph. Let , = | | and = | |. Given an edge , ? , it can be represented as node pair ( , ), where , ? . Now let ? R ? represents the corresponding symmetric adjacency matrix, where matrix element , indicates whether edge ( , ) ? . For node features, let ? R ? represents feature matrix, where matrix element , represents the ? element of feature vector of node . Now given a partially network = ( , ), the problem is to predict whether a missing link edge ? ? ? = ? ? exists. Therefore, the task is to find a model function ( | ) for any edge , such that ( + | ) = 1 when edge + ? is a positive edge sample, and ( ? | ) = 0 when edge ? ? ? is certainly a negative edge sample, where is the parameter of the model function. However, as we have no idea about whether edge ? ? ? is certainly a negative sample, we prefer to supoose that the prediction value of a positive sample is higher than that of a negative sample, namely ( + | ) > ( ? | ), when + is a positive edge sample and ? is a uncertain negative sample. Intuitively, a harder learning objective is to rank all edge samples by maximising the difference of ( + | ) and ( ? | ). Formally, we can optimize the model by the following objective loss function, squared least surrogate loss [12,27]:
where is a weight hyperparamter of L2 regularization for model generalization. Generally, the parameters of the model can be optimized and approached by stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method.

div.head: Model Buildup
div.p: To solve the problem described in the former subsection, we propose a Path-aware Siamese Graph neural network model, or simply PSG model. In the following, we present the details of the proposed PSG model.

div.head: Model Architecture.
div.p: In general, PSG model is a combinatorial model, which can be represented as a function of combination of two associated paired nodes, as shown in Formula 2.

Each associated node can be learned and represented as a hidden feature embedding based on a representation learning function. So the model can be reformed as a link prediction function of representation function of two associated paired nodes, as shown in Formula 3.
As the ogbl-ddi network is an undirected graph, representation functions of nodes can share the same one, as shown in Formula 4.

In the part of related work, GNN network has been widely applied for the task of link prediction. Here, GNN network is also adopted as a representation function model of graph nodes, as shown in Formula 5.
For the same reason, MLP is applied as link prediction function, as shown in Formula 6.

Based on the above combinatorial model framework, PSG can be divided into four parts: edge featuring, node encoder, link predicter and pairwise objective loss function. Firstly, edge featuring part generates edge features for any given node pairs based on shortest path distances of sampled relay paths. Then node encoder part generates hidden feature embedding representation of any given node based on the generated edge feaures and neighborhood node features in a siamese network manner. After that, link prediction part decodes the former encoded node feature embedding representations of associated paired nodes. Finally, the part of pairwise objective loss function computes the difference between the prediction values of positive edge sample and sampled negative edge sample. The overview of the PSG model architecture is shown in Figure 1.
In the following, we will present more details of the four parts.

div.head: Edge
div.p: Featuring. For traditional machine learning task, feature engineering can directly improve the model performance due to relativeness improvement of features. Therefore, a direct idea is to utilize the edge link features for the link prediction task. However, missing links do not have direct edge features. A possible way is to calculate the Shortest Path Distance(SPD) [10,28] for any given paired nodes, or simply called edge. To improve the path structure capturing ability, a relay path sampling method is applied to generate multiple relay path-aware SPDs. For robustness, each relay path sampling selects a random sampling area and relay nodes. Then a relay path-aware edge feature is generated as expectation of SPDs through relay paths. Such a process is executed for serveral times, namely . Hence, we get edge feature vector ? with dimension . Finally, an edge feature tensor with dimension ? ? is generated.

div.head: Node Encoder.
div.p: For representation of two associated paired nodes, a shared siamese graph neural network(GNN) model is used to encode the node features and path-aware edge features of neighborhood. The shared siamese GNN network model shares the network structure and network weights for representation of associated nodes from both positive edge sample and negative edge sample. Similar to GraphSAGE [11], the node encoder block mainly contains neighborhood sampling, neighborhood aggregation and node update. Besides, path-aware edge features are integrated into the shared siamese GNN network, which can improve the contrastive learning of different relay path features between positive edge sample and negative edge sample. Specifically, Formula 5 can be depicted by Formula 7.

where ( ) represents the r-hop neighborhood node set of node , in which the distance to node is not greater than . And A represents the aggregation function of neighborhood nodes, which is set to as default.

div.head: Link Predicter.
div.p: As a decoder, MLP [29] is adopted as link predicter function. Like node encoder block, link predicter block also shares the network structure and network weights for decoding of associated nodes from both positive edge sample and negative edge sample. In addition, feature intersection is applied within this block. Formula 6 is rewritten as Formula 8.
where ? represents Hadamard product and W 4 is the corresponding weight matrix.

div.head: Pairwise Objective Loss Function .
div.p: To garantee the generalized performance of the proposed PSG model, the former pairwise objective loss function depicted by Formula 1 can be reformed as Formula 9.
where W i ? is a weight matrix of the parameter , and is the corresponding weight hyperparamter.
In addition, dropout is also applied in the shared node encoder and link predicter.

div.head: EXPERIMENTS
div.p: Below we evaluate the performance of our algorithm PSG on OGB [8] dataset ogbl-ddi.

div.head: Datasets and task
div.p: As mentioned befor, the dataset ogbl-ddi is a homogeneous, unweighted, undirected graph, representing the drug-drug interaction network [9], containing 4267 nodes and 2135822 edges. Based on the protein-target split of OGB, the graph is splited into training set, validation set and test set, which contain 1067911 edges, 133489 edges and 133489 edges respectively. The following is about the graph statistic analysis of the training graph. It is figured out that there are 142099673 triangles. Graph density is 0.117. The number of community detection is 5. Network diameter is also 5. The task is to predict drug-drug interactions given information on already known drug-drug interactions, which can be reformed as to rank true drug-drug interaction higher than false drug-drug interaction.

div.head: Baselines
div.p: We compare our algorithm PSG with PLNLP [12], GraphSAGE+Edge Attr [28] and other GNN based algorihtms in the leaderboad of OGB. PLNLP introduce pairwise loss function and data augmentation based on the framework of GraphSAGE node encoder and MLP link predicter. GraphSAGE+Edge Attr utilizes distance encoding to integrate edge features based on GraphSAGE encoder and MLP link predicter. Our algorithm PSG is to capture both node and edge features of neighborhood nodes in shared Siamese GNN in the same framework of GraphSAGE node encoder and MLP link predicter.

div.head: Metrics and settings
div.p: Recommended by OGB, the evaluation metric is Hits@K, which is the ratio of positive edges that are ranked at K-place or above, among a set of approximately 100,000 randomly-sampled negative drug interactions. Here, K = 20. The hyperparameters for PSG is summurized in Tabel 1. The experiments are executed in PyG with Pytorch underthe circumstance of Tesla V100 GPU(32G RAM).

div.head: Experimental Results
div.p: As required, our algorithm PSG is conducted for ten times with random seeds for each parameter group. We list several performance results on the test set and the validation set in Table 2 with different parameter groups in terms of average plus standard deviation. As a contrast, the results of baselines are also extracted from the ogbl-ddi leaderboad. The proposed algorithm PSG beats the stateof-the-art algorithm PLNLP in the leaderboad and achieves 2.2% more performance improvement in terms of average test Hits@20. 0.9118 ? 0.0235 0.8161 ? 0.0232 PSG(epochs = 500) 0.9284 ? 0.0047 0.8306 ? 0.0134 PSG(epochs = 600) 0.9189 ? 0.0298 0.8562 ? 0.0181 PSG(epochs = 750) 0.9065 ? 0.0391 0.8651 ? 0.0156 PSG(epochs = 1000) 0.9072 ? 0.0246 0.8673 ? 0.0253 PSG(epochs = 1500) 0.9125 ? 0.0214 0.8681 ? 0.0161

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we propose a PSG algorithm for link prediction of drug-drug interaction network, which includes edge featuring, node encoder, link predicter and pairwise objective loss function methods. The PSG algorithm achieves the best performance of the leaderboad on ogb-ddi dataset, which improves the Hits@20 performance by 2.2% than the state-of-the-art algorithm PLNLP on the test set. Our algorithm provides an enlightening idea for contrastive learning of positive edge sample and negative edge sample in terms of relay path sampling. We will optimize contrastive learning and edge featuring in future work. Node featuring is another direction in our future work, especially pretraining and content embedding.
